Overview
Seeking knowledge is required of every Muslim, and as corruption spreads on the land and inequality grows internationally, knowledge of how to earn a halal living is critical. I believe taking halal rizq(sustenance) seriously can be a source of our healing and can bring balance to our world.

The phone in your pocket connects you with cobalt miners in Kolwezi, Congo, designers in San Francisco, USA, and oil refineries in Iraq. The money you spend on that phone is your vote for the hundreds of processes it takes to make, market, ship, and sell it to you. Are you ready to accept responsibility for your actions? Are you ready to face the miners in Congo? Are you willing to defend your vote before God (SWT)?

Are we except from being considered accomplices to oppression that happens in the value chains of our products simply because we are unaware? 

Ignorance is an excuse until you know better. In the light of the global wars, Occupy Wall Street, and the consequences of climate collapse, more people are waking up to the idea that many elements of our compounding crisis are by-products of the systems we use to get and spend our sustenance. There are movements, like the boycott, divest, and sanction (BDS) movement that have shown how we can follow our ethics in choosing what not to buy. This book will examine what to buy instead. 

“...I did not have any authority over you. I only called you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; blame yourselves.”
-Surah Ibrahim Ayah 22

Muslims represent nearly a quarter of the population of the planet, and we can show leadership by developing products and services that follow the beautiful advice of the Prophet of God (S,) who has said in an authentic (sahih) hadith: 

“Leave that which makes you doubt for that which does not make you doubt.” 
- Sunan an-Nasa’i 5711; In-book reference : Book 51, Hadith 173

In an era of destabilizing change and disquiet, we all want our prayers to be answered, and the Prophet (S) has given us a clue as to the relationship between halal rizk and answered prayers:

Abu Huraira reported Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) as saying: O people, Allah is Good and He therefore, accepts only that which is good. …  He then made a mention of a person who travels widely, his hair disheveled and covered with dust(a person desperately needy). He lifts his hand towards the sky (and thus makes the supplication): "O Lord, O Lord," whereas his diet is unlawful, his drink is unlawful, and his clothes are unlawful and his nourishment is unlawful. How can then his supplication be accepted?
Sahih Muslim 1015

It has been said that true wealth is contentedness, a path towards contentedness in this life, and confidence on the day we will be held accountable to how we earned and spent our money is increasing our efforts to gain knowledge in what is كَسْبٍ طَيِّبٍ (pure earning) and how best to spend it..

By reading this book, the reader will:
Take stock of their transactions and work to purify their regular expenditures
Learn how to earn a halal livelihood and make business a part of our worship.
Be inspired to establish Baraka-based businesses that can support a parallel economy, one where Muslims can confidently acquire pure goods and services.
Be a part of showing leadership to a world questioning capitalism without alternatives.

About the Author
Bilal Ghalib is an educator, entrepreneur and facilitator with 15 years of experience training entrepreneurs internationally. 
In 2016, he co-founded Bloom.pm, a social impact entrepreneurship training organization and education technology company. He’s also an advisor for Project Defy, a non-profit organization working to redefine education in India. Since 2015, he has been running Nur Coop, a business that seeks to bless the entire value chain from “Dirt to Delivery.” 

I have 8 intentions for writing this book:
To open the blessings of God to our beloved Muslim Community by sharing knowledge on halal rizk(sustenance).
 To support more people to spend their money in ways that are regenerative and uplifting of the people and ecological systems that underlie their purchases.
To transform my own eyes and others, and to see what happens to businesses that see their customers, the natural world, and their business with the eye of the heart. 
To increase my taqwa of God(SWT) when he mentions in the Quran “O you who believe! Eat of the lawful and pure things that We have provided you.” [2:172]” that it is God(SWT) providing my sustenance. And I must seek the lawful and pure and increase my efforts in ensuring my consumption is within the good pleasure of God.
To inspire people by demonstrating that the Muslim economy can bring about a beautiful transformation. 
To alter my perception of success and increase my contentedness.  
To share my intuition that Muslims can be a blessing for this world by their deeper concern on the next.
To invite Muslims, and myself, to decommodify the world and to return to a pre-modern way of seeing the signs of God in all things and all people. And to witness the accompanying change in my interactions, including commercial interactions, with all things. 

  The Market 
The book has three target audiences:
Primary target: 
Early-stage Muslim Entrepreneurs in the UK and the USA
Why is this book unique to them? Young Muslims are seeking security in an age of instability. Modern wisdom suggests they start multiple income streams, be their boss, and “ditch the 9-5” even if they could find one. The book attempts to direct them away from repeating the methods of doing business that have led to the age of instability in the first place and to seek trust not in themselves and their capabilities, to first put their relationship with God right, to purify their expenditures, and then to set an intention and execute on creating a taqwa-filled baraka based business that in aggregate can act as a lighthouse in an age of darkness.

The book provides a fresh perspective on business ethics through the lens of Islamic principles, offering universal wisdom about trust, relationships, and sustainable commerce that can appeal to anyone seeking alternatives to traditional business models. Affinity Groups:

Competition

Book: The Book Of The Proprieties of Earning and Living is a translation of Al Ghazali, a wonderful resource for the principles that will define the book I’m seeking to write. It’s for the person interested in primary sources. 
Hardcover.

- this book discusses economics from a business administration angle. It’s written as a text book and goes over broad subjects from HR to finance and accounting and setting up a business. My focus is towards inspiring producers and consumers to alter their purchase/production decisions by directing attention towards the problems people see with our ecology, our social ails and how we call to our lord wanting support when we know from the hadith: https://sunnah.com/nawawi40:10 - that unless we purify our clothes, our food, our drink - unless we purify the way we seek our sustenance that this hadith indicates our duaas are less likely to be answered, and God is capable of all things. My goal is not to describe a halal economics precisely, or to define where things are going wrong.
My goal is to activate people who become more and more careful and direct more and more of their economic power towards people who are more and more careful. Amplifying our strength and building the alternatives while ensuring our akhiras.

I've reviewed your book proposal and the additional themes you've mentioned. This is a fascinating intersection of Islamic principles, economic justice, human connection, and sustainable business practices. Let me ask you some thought-provoking questions to help draw out more content and organize these ideas:

1. You mentioned the soul needing to catch up with physical movement - can you share a personal experience where moving too fast in business caused you to lose touch with your spiritual center? How did you recognize and address this?

2. The concept of beauty as a business metric is intriguing - could you elaborate on what specific qualities or characteristics would make a business "beautiful" from an Islamic perspective?

3. When you talk about the colosseum effect and modern entertainment as pressure release valves for societal tension - how do you envision halal businesses could provide healthier alternatives for community catharsis?

4. In considering the 8 forms of capital from permaculture - how might these different forms of wealth align with Islamic principles of barakah? Could you give examples of businesses successfully operating with multiple forms of capital?

5. The relationship between wu wei (non-action) and Islamic concepts is fascinating - how do you see this connecting to the Prophet Muhammad's (S) business practices? What lessons can modern entrepreneurs draw from this synthesis?

6. Your proposal touches on building parallel economies - what are some concrete examples you've seen of successful small-scale halal value chains that maintain human relationships throughout the process?

7. How has your experience with Nur Coop demonstrated the practical challenges and opportunities in creating businesses that prioritize relationships and baraka over pure profit?

8. You mentioned the idea of being "in touch" and closer to things - could you share a story about how physical proximity or direct relationship with products/services changed your understanding of halal business?

9. What role do you see technology playing in your vision of barakanomics? How can we use modern tools while maintaining the human scale and relationship-centered approach you're advocating?

10. When you discuss "answering to the miners in Congo" - could you elaborate on how you envision businesses practically implementing this level of supply chain consciousness while remaining viable?

Would you like to start with any particular question, or shall we work on incorporating these themes into a more detailed outline?
